Dear Mr. Hannah:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 06/06/2023, 06/07/2023 and 06/09/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing
rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15
days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact the area
manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4112-1-a Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42
USC 671 shall not permit a child caring institution
staff member to begin working unless all of the
following has been completed using the forms, and
in the manner, prescribed by the department:
a) A criminal record check as referenced in R
400.4113(f), including a fingerprint-based check of
national crime information databases, unless an

alternative criminal history check has been
approved by the federal government.
Three of twenty-one employee files failed to document that a criminal history check was
completed prior to hire.
CCI Rule 400.4112-1-b (1) Child caring institutions shall not permit a child
caring institution staff member to begin working
unless all of the following has been completed
using the forms, and in the manner, prescribed by
the department:
(b) A check of Michigan’s child abuse and neglect
central registry or Canadian provincial agency as
referenced in R 400.4113(i).
One of twenty-one employee files reviewed failed to document that a central registry
check had been completed prior to date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-c (1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule: (c) Verification of high school diploma or GED
when specified by rule.
Two of twenty-one employee files reviewed failed to have documentation of a high school
diploma, as required per job description.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-e (1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule: (e) Three dated references which are obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated to the
employee and which are less than 12 months old.
Two of twenty-one employee files reviewed lacked the required references in the required
timeframes. One of the two had a reference request form that was not dated and second
employee file had a reference request form that was dated after the date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-h (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule: (h) A statement from the employee regarding
any convictions.

One of twenty-one employee files reviewed failed to include a written statement from the
employee regarding confirmed convictions.
CCI Rule 400.4113-1-j (1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule: (j) A written evaluation of the employee’s
performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee’s performance annually thereafter.
Seven of twenty-one employee files reviewed did not include documentation of timely
completion of their evaluation after their probationary period or annual review.
CCI Rule 400.4114-1 (1) The licensee shall document, prior to
employment, that each employee and volunteer
who has contact with residents 4 or more hours per
week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free
from communicable tuberculosis. Freedom from
communicable tuberculosis shall be verified within
the 1 year period before employment and shall be
verified every 1 year after the last verification or
prior to the expiration of the current verification.
Two of twenty-one employee files that were reviewed failed to document TB results as
required by policy. The results for one employee were not legible and another employee
had no TB results in the HR file.
CCI Rule 400.4115-1 (1) A person certified within the preceding 36
months in first aid and within the preceding 24
months in age-appropriate cardiopulmonary
resuscitation by the American Red Cross, the
American Heart Association, or an equivalent
organization or institution approved by the
department shall be on duty at all times when 1 or
more children are present.
Three of twenty-one employee files did not have documentation of current completion of
CPR and First Aid training. Note: CFC job description requires direct care staff to be
trained in CPR.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-a (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after

discharge: (a) The date of and reason for
discharge, and the new location of the child.
One of two closed case files reviewed failed to document the date and reason for
discharge for the youth.
CCI Rule 400.4166-2 (2) For an unplanned discharge, an institution shall
provide a brief summary or other documentation of
the circumstances surrounding the discharge.
One of two closed case files reviewed failed to document a brief summary of the
circumstances surrounding the unplanned discharge of the youth.
CCI Rule 400.4144-1 (1) An initial health screening shall be completed
for each resident within 24 hours of admission to a
facility.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include documentation of the completion of an
initial health screen. This is a repeat violation from the 2022 Interim inspection.
CCI Rule 400.4152-1-c (1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record: (c) A brief
description of the resident’s preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional
state at the time of admission.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include documentation of a brief description of
the preparation for placement and physical and emotional state at the time of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4152-1-h (1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record: (h) A brief
description of the circumstances leading to the
need for care.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include documentation of the circumstances
leading to the need for care.
CCI Rule 400.4152-1-I (1) At the time of admission, all of the following
shall be in the resident’s case record: (i)
Documentation that the grievance policy was
provided as required in R 400.4132.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include documentation that the grievance policy
was provided as required by policy. This is a repeat violation from the 2022 Interim
inspection.

CCI Rule 400.4156-4 (4) The social service worker shall sign and date
the initial treatment plan.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include the signature of the social services
worker on the updated service plan.
CCI Rule 400.4156-5 (5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the updated treatment plan.
One of three youth files reviewed did not include the signature of the social services
supervisor on the updated service plan.
CCI Rule 400.4155-1 (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each resident
within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of three youth files reviewed included an initial service plan that was completed and
signed after 30 days of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4156-1 1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an updated treatment plan for each
resident at least once every 90-calendar days
following the initial treatment plan.
One of three youth files reviewed included an updated service plan that was completed
and signed after 90 days of the completion of the ISP.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-b (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge: (b) A brief summary or other
documentation of the services provided while in
residence, including medical and dental services.
One of two closed youth files reviewed failed to include documentation of services
provided while in care, including medical and dental services.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-c (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge: (c) An assessment of the resident’s
needs that remain to be met.

One of two closed youth files reviewed failed to include documentation of an assessment
of the youth’s needs that remained to be met at the time of discharge.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-d (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge: (d) Any services that will be provided
by the facility after discharge.
Two of two closed youth files reviewed failed to include documentation of services to be
provided after discharge.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-e (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge: (e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental
follow up that is needed, have been reviewed with
the resident and with the parent and with the
responsible case manager.
Two of two closed youth files reviewed failed to include documentation of a statement
that the discharge plan recommendations had been reviewed with the resident, parent
and case manager.
CCI Rule 400.4166-1-f 1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge: (f) The name and official title of the
person to whom the resident was discharged.
One of two closed youth files reviewed failed to include documentation of the name and
title of the person to whom the youth was discharged.
CCI Rule 400.4414 (1) The water supply for an institution shall comply
with the requirements of the department of public
health. (2) Each sink, lavatory, bath, shower,
drinking fountain, and other water outlet shall be
supplied with safe and potable water which is
sufficient in quantity and pressure to meet the
conditions of peak demand. Hot and cold or
tempered water shall be provided in each sink,
lavatory, bath, and shower. Hot water temperatures
shall not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit at outlets
accessible to residents.

Environmental Inspection documented that water temperature at some of the hand sinks
exceeded 120 degrees Fahrenheit.
CCI Rule 400.4407-6 (6) Plumbing fixtures and water and waste pipes
shall be properly installed and maintained in good
working condition.
Environmental Inspection documented that hand sink faucets and toilet were damaged in
Unit 3 of the facility.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• There was no technical assistance provided to the agency.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
The agency was provided with consultation regarding recreation activities and
food portions for youth in the program. A request by the youth for more variety
in the recreation activities was shared with the program supervisors, residential
care supervisors and the clinical director. Information was also share with
staff and supervision regarding the feedback from youth requesting larger
portion sizes during meals. It was suggested that staff incorporate education
regarding standard food portion sizes and how they correlate to physical and
mental health. This education can create awareness for the youth and assist
them in understanding the national recommendations for standard food
portions.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were two incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period. Special Investigation 2023C0000295 dated 05/30/2023 found
the facility in noncompliance for rule 400.4112 Staff Qualifications, 400.4131
Compliance with Child Protection Law, 400.4109 Program Statement, 400.4126
Sufficiency of Staff and 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions. A
corrective action plan is currently pending. Special Investigation 2023C0000074
dated 01/18/2023 found the facility in noncompliance for rule 400.4112, Staff
Qualifications and rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions. A
corrective action plan dated 02/27/2023 was approved that included the staff
member involved being terminated, training for staff, and review of current staff
discipline process. Quarterly unannounced visits to the facility have been
completed and implementation of their corrective action plan has been noted.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The facility had fourteen special investigations during this period under review with
six resulting in corrective action plans. The non-compliances included staff

following facility internal policies, sufficiency of staffing, proper restraints, incident
reporting, mandated reporter guidelines and proper staff supervision. The agency
also had one corrective action plan as a result of their 2022 interim inspection.
The non-compliances included case file documentation and initial health screening
requirements. Quarterly unannounced visits to the facility have been completed
and implementation of their corrective action plan has been noted.
Financial Overview
A review of the financial documents for CFC were reviewed. No areas of concern
were noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was completed and submitted for review. The
assessment documented areas that the agency is looking to address via
Corrective Action Plans. The facility has been successful in demonstrating
compliance with their RCAN contract during this review period. The assessment
also indicated an appropriate plan for continued monitoring of compliance.
Staff and Youth Interviews
A total of six staff were interviewed as a part of the renewal inspection. This
included three direct care staff, two supervisors and one administrator. No
concerns were noted, and the employees provided positive feedback regarding the
company and the improvements that they believe the current administration is
making. Those changes include, but are not limited to, adjustment in staff to youth
ratio, new CPI protocol and training for staff and use of compliance forms to
document strengths and areas of improvement for the agency. All of the staff
shared some of the challenges associated with the changes at the facility within
the last year, but indicated that they are adjusting appropriately. The
administrative staff have expressed their desire to continue working with the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing and the Department of Health and Human
Services for improved outcomes for those serviced by the facility.
The facility currently has placement of 16 youth. Four youth were interviewed as a
part of the renewal inspection. All youth were able to identify positive aspects of
the program. A consistent theme among the youth was a desire for increased food
portions. Protocol and the federal standard for portion sizes was discussed with
the youth. They also confirmed that they receive snacks daily. Youth reported
having good relationships with most of the staff. The youth did report a desire to
have more recreation options available to them. They were advised that this could
be discussed with CFC administration.
Description of Agency Walk Through

A walk through of the agency was completed and the facility was found to be
appropriately staffed and very well maintained. No areas of concern were noted
VII. RECOMMENDATION
The agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules. SIR
2023C0000295 recommends a First Provisional license which the agency has
appealed and the processes is ongoing. This renewal will be approved for payment
purposes upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan.
